awd_titl_txt: Building professional capital in elementary science teaching through a district-wide networked improvement community model
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will focus on a networked improvement community (NIC) model of professional learning that shifts K-5 science instruction from traditional approaches to a three-dimensional design as outlined in the Next Generation Science Standards. The need to make this shift stems from the school district's decision to address inequities in science as some schools offer minimal to no science instruction during the elementary years. The NIC model will draw on expertise from school personnel and university partners to ensure that students will have access to and benefit from authentic model-based inquiry daily in the early grades. This model embraces the challenges of scale and sustainability by targeting the design and substance of professional learning and its organization within the district, balancing integration with existing system infrastructure, and shifting the system based on theory-driven practices. To prepare teachers for this major change, professional development will shift from: (1) training on the use of kit-based curricular materials to professional learning grounded in NGSS-inspired sets of practices and tools; (2) working as individual practitioners to teaching as collaborative investigations; (3) using centralized efforts to distributed knowledge-building and leadership; (4) learning science as decontextualized facts to deep engagement with real-world phenomena; and (5) teaching lessons as prescribed by curriculum to a focus on responsive teaching and building on students' funds of knowledge. The NIC model will provide a pathway for integrating and implementing these shifts via a multilevel, knowledge-building, problem-solving system. This system will go beyond a single focus on improving students' understanding of science content to incorporating teaching practices that advances knowledge about student's written and spoken scientific language and use of explanations and arguments. Through the NIC model all K-5 elementary students in the district will benefit from a rigorous and equitable approach to science learning. 

This project will feature a multi-level model involving university educators and researchers and school district practitioners in an effort to co-defined problems of practice valuable to both parties. A mixed methods research design will examine how the NIC model develops professional capital through changes in implementation over multiple iterations. These changes will be captured through short and long-term instruments. Regarding the shorter term, practical measures sensitive to change and directly tied to small manageable, short-term goals will provide quick responses to everyday real-time questions. These measures will help assess specific improvement goals using language relevant and meaningful to researchers and practitioners. For longer term goals, in-depth case studies, interviews, observations, pre-posttests, surveys, and questionnaires will collect data on several variables critical to documenting improvements at the teacher and student levels. Both sets of data will generate knowledge about ambitious and equitable science teaching practices with a focus on students' cultural and linguistic resources and experiences. Through such pathways, knowledge will be generated on teachers' and students' growth as active builders and collaborators in the development of improved learning and experiences. The outcomes will identify critical facets that support advances and sustainability that illuminate variations within the district to better understand what works, for whom, and under what conditions. the research findings will also be used to inform decision making about teaching science at the elementary grades and to further refine equity-based practices, resources, and tools for building on students' funds of knowledge vital to supporting, sustaining, and scaling educational outcomes for all students in the district and beyond. 

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in this program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justifications for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With support from the National Science Foundation, researchers partnered with district personnel and over 850 teachers from five districts, led hundreds of hours of professional development, and learned from 50 case study teachers who helped articulate critical and cultural approaches to Ambitious Science Teaching, C2AST, from 2019-2024. The research-practice partnership work shifted with the pandemic as teachers moved to online then back to in-person teaching, and wrestled with how to center equity and teacher learning.

 

Intellectual merit 

We ran both large-scale professional learning to support shifts in science teaching practice and worked with smaller communities of teachers to take curricular and pedagogical risks in their classrooms. Across districts, we employed several professional learning approaches, each with its attributes and limitations, given the shifting priorities of districts and teachers.

Cross-district professional learning. For the first two years of the project, as a part of our large-scale work with Seattle Public Schools, we designed an all-comers model to support teachers in noticing for equity. On the heels of a curriculum adoption, we created opportunities for teachers to notice and attend to students’ ideas and engage them in sense-making conversations. We made strategic shifts in the curriculum such as adding modeling, evidence trackers, and discourse strategies, and drew teachers’ attention to these shifts. Teachers engaged as learners, designed supports for their students, and used frameworks to notice how students were engaging. Researchers analyzed students’ scientifically important and divergent approaches and shared them with teachers. District staff, researchers, and teacher leaders helped design the professional learning, which ran for two years, and then district staff ran the professional learning for the following year, supporting 1200 elementary teachers in total.

Critical and Cultural Small-scale Professional Learning. In our work with SPS and other districts in the first three years, we ran opt-in professional learning with groups of 10-30 teachers, which helped teachers (and researchers) question what counts as science, how science is done, and who gets to do science. During this year-long, PL teachers learned about new concepts, shared stories, and brainstormed with colleagues on how to shift instruction. These efforts were designed by researchers, and ultimately districts were not able to maintain professional learning over time. Some teachers made small changes to their approach to teaching with new tools and approaches, while others shifted their purpose for teaching and the kinds of socially responsive phenomena students engaged with.

Teacher Learning Communities. In the last year of the project, we co-designed a professional learning community model to center equity and justice with SPS district staff, researchers, and 30 teacher leaders from across the district. We ran a similar model in two other districts with 17 additional teachers. Grade-level teams met monthly and worked on one of three lines of equity inquiry: 1) Expansive Explanations: How can we support students in constructing their own explanations (i.e., sense-making)? 2) Funds of Knowledge: How can we utilize students’ existing knowledge throughout the unit? 3) Power Dynamics: What race, language, and gender power dynamics need addressing in the classroom and in science? We met as a larger community three times to come to collectively define equity-based practices. Teachers made shifts in their teaching (see Figures 1 and 2, and stories from a PLC focused on funds of knowledge), shared videos of their teaching, and raised critical questions about how science is typically taught and how to broaden participation in their classrooms. Notably, SPS plans to continue this model next year.

Shifts over time in professional collaborations. Figure 2 illustrates the percentage of teachers’ networks focused on different C2AST content areas by year and cohort. In the first three years of the project, adapting science curricula and understanding science content were focal areas of professional collaboration. However, by the third cohort (amid the COVID-19 pandemic and renewed social justice movement in the U.S.), there was an increased concentration of collaborations taking up how to include nonwestern scientific ideas in their practice, justice-centered instruction, and instruction for supporting diverse students. In the final year of the project, we asked two questions due to the shift in PLC content focus: shifting classroom power dynamics and helping students ask critical questions. As can be seen, a large percentage of teachers’ professional networks centered on these two topics.

 

Broader impacts

As part of the final year of the project, the AST website (https://ambitiousscienceteaching.org/) was updated with new content and launched in January 2024. We focused on centering equity, stories from teachers and professional learning providers, and broadening the community. Based on website analytics, since the re-launch, the website has been visited 91,976 times by 25,029 new users since January 1, 2024. We also held a two-day meeting with district leaders from across the country, in which we shared and developed 14 new resources for professional learning providers
